1.text: These are also proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.

2.text: It is the glory of God to conceal a thing: but the honor of kings is to search out a matter.

3.text: The heaven for hight, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings is unsearchable.

4.text: Take away the dross from the silver, and there shall come forth a vessel for the finer.

5.text: Take away the wicked from before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.

6.text: Put not forth thyself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great men:

7.text: For better it is that it be said to thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldst be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thy eyes have seen.

8.text: Go not forth hastily to strive, lest thou know not what to do in the end thereof, when thy neighbor hath put thee to shame.

9.text: Debate thy cause with thy neighbor himself; and reveal not a secret to another:

10.text: Lest he that heareth it put thee to shame, and thy infamy turn not away.

11.text: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in pictures of silver.

12.text: As an ear-ring of gold, and an ornament of fine gold, so is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.

13.text: As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to them that send him: for he refresheth the soul of his masters.

14.text: Whoever boasteth himself of a false gift is like clouds and wind without rain.

15.text: By long forbearing is a prince persuaded, and a soft tongue breaketh the bone.

16.text: Hast thou found honey? eat so much as is sufficient for thee, lest thou be filled with it, and vomit it.

17.text: Withdraw thy foot from thy neighborâ€™s house; lest he be weary of thee, and so hate thee.

18.text: A man that beareth false witness against his neighbor is a maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow.

19.text: Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble is like a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.

20.text: As he that taketh away a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon nitre; so is he that singeth songs to a heavy heart.

21.text: If thy enemy shall hunger, give him bread to eat; and if he shall thirst, give him water to drink:

22.text: For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the LORD will reward thee.

23.text: The north wind driveth away rain: so doth an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.

24.text: It is better to dwell in a corner of the house-top, than with a brawling woman and in a wide house.

25.text: As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country.

26.text: A righteous man falling down before the wicked is as a turbid fountain, and a corrupt spring.

27.text: It is not good to eat much honey: so for men to search their own glory is not glory.

28.text: He that hath no rule over his own spirit is like a city that is broken down, and without walls.
